We shall demonstrate below by an exact numerical diagonalization of a 3D lattice model that the Majorana flat bands remain robust beyond the minimal low energy surface theory. Their  stability however can be deduced from the surface theory alone and relies on the time reversal symmetry ${\cal T}$ and the bulk-boundary correspondence present in the Weyl semimetal.  The most general surface Hamiltonian consistent with these requirements is of the form $h({\bm k})=({\bm v}_{k_y}\cdot{\bm s}) k_x-\mu_{k_y}$ for $|k_y|<K$ where both the velocity vector and the chemical potential are even functions of $k_y$. Time reversal symmetry further permits a term  $({\bm u}_{k_y}\cdot{\bm s}) k_y$ but this is not consistent with $h({\bm k})$ describing the surface state of a Weyl semimetal \cite{remark1}.

For each $k_y$ one can now perform an SU(2) rotation in spin space to bring $h({\bm k})$ to the form indicated in Eq.\ (\ref{h2}). Because the pairing term in the BdG Hamiltonian (\ref{h3})  is not affected by this transformation the calculation demonstrating the zero modes proceeds as before, with the result (\ref{h5}) modified in two minor ways: $v$ and $\mu$ may  now depend on $k_y$ and the spinor structure reflects the SU(2) rotation. The exact zero modes persist for all allowed values of $k_y$ in this more general case. 

It is easy to see that breaking ${\cal T}$ lifts the zero modes: for instance interpolating between $-\Delta_0$ and $+\Delta_0$ through complex values of $\Delta(x)$ moves MZMs to finite energies. Flat Majorana bands are thus protected by ${\cal T}$ and by translation symmetry that is necessary to establish the underlying momentum space Weyl structure.

We now briefly address the proximity effect in a Weyl semimetal with broken ${\cal T}$. Although there are currently no known materials in this class a proposed engineered layered compound \cite{burkov1} holds some promise. Here the minimal case has ${\cal N}=2$ and a single Fermi arc in the surface as illustrated in Fig.\ \ref{fig1}b. For simplicity and concreteness we assume that the two Weyl nodes are related by a mirror symmetry ${\cal M}$ with $y=0$ the mirror plane. It is then natural to form Cooper pairs from ${\cal M}$-conjugate partners at crystal momenta $(k_x,k_y)$ and  $(k_x,-k_y)$. For $k_y\to 0$ we are necessarily pairing electrons with the same spin and must therefore employ odd-parity pair potential $\Delta_{\bm k}\sim k_y$. Such an odd-parity pair potential can be generated by proximity to an $s$-wave SC provided  there is a significant spin-orbit coupling present in the interface \cite{suk1}. The relevant low-energy BdG Hamiltonian then reads

and has a spectrum $E_{\bm k}=\sqrt{(vk_x-\mu)^2+(v_\Delta k_y)^2}$. For $\mu=0$ this corresponds to a single gapless Majorana mode (with anisotropic dispersion) and a point node located at the center of the surface BZ. For nonzero $\mu$ the node is shifted by $\mu/v$ along the $k_x$ axis. Furthermore, when the mirror symmetry is broken the node can move away from the axis. Since all discrete symmetries are now broken (except for the particle-hole symmetry intrinsic to all BdG Hamiltonians) we expect the massless Majorana mode to be stable to all perturbations that do not destroy the SC order or the underlying Weyl semimetal. 

To summarize, SC proximity effect in the surface of a Weyl semimetal produces an interesting interfacial superconductor with unique properties. In ${\cal T}$-preserving Weyl materials (relevant to the recently identified Weyl semimetals  \cite{hasan1,lv1,yan1,lv2,yang1,hasan2})  the observable signature consists of protected flat Majorana bands that occur at zero energy in a linear Josephson $\pi$-junction defined on the surface. The flat bands span projections of the bulk Weyl points with opposite chirality onto the one dimensional edge BZ along the junction. We have demonstrated the existence and robustness of such flat bands in a minimal model with ${\cal N}=4$ Weyl nodes but expect the signature to survive in materials with larger ${\cal N}$. The flat bands are experimentally observable by tunneling into the junction region \cite{Pill1,Seu1} and are likely to have consequences for the current-phase relation of the junction. They also provide a unique opportunity to study interaction effects in Majorana systems because even weak interactions can have profound consequences in a flat-band setting  \cite{potter1,chiu1}. Unlike the Fu-Kane superconductor, where vortex core MZMs occur against a bulk insulator with a large gap, the phenomena discussed here take place on the surface of a gapless semimetal. Bulk gapless excitations can thus complicate their experimental detection. We note, however, that the density of states in a Weyl semimetal $D(\omega)\sim \omega^2$ at low energy and will thus be vanishingly small near the $\omega=0$ neutrality point. Majorana flat bands on the other hand give rise to a divergent density of states and thus should be well visible in a tunneling experiment.

Majorana surface states, including flat bands, have been theoretically predicted to occur in various 2D and 3D topological and nodal superconductors \cite{ReviewQiZhang,schnyder1,meng1,cho1,fawang1,wong1,hosur1}. With the exception of high-$T_c$ cuprates, where dispersionless edge states are known to exist (and were reinterpreted recently as Majorana flat bands \cite{potter1}), these have not been observed experimentally because of the general paucity of topological superconductors. Majorana flat bands discussed in this Letter only require ingredients that are currently known to exist -- a ${\cal T}$-preserving Weyl semimetal interfaced with an ordinary superconductor -- and are thus promising candidates for experimental detection. The massless Majorana mode predicted to exist in the surface of a ${\cal T}$-breaking Weyl semimetal will become observable once such materials have been identified.

For $\epsilon\neq 0$ the arcs rotate and curve as illustrated in Fig.\ \ref{fig2}e. Majorana flat bands however remain robustly present in this low symmetry case (Fig.\ \ref{fig2}g). They now also appear for a junction parallel to the $x$ crystal direction (Fig.\ \ref{fig2}h) because the Weyl points project onto distinct $k_x$ momenta in the boundary BZ. 

We now briefly address the proximity effect in a Weyl semimetal with broken ${\cal T}$. Although there are currently no known materials in this class a proposed engineered layered compound \cite{burkov1} holds some promise. Here the minimal case has ${\cal N}=2$ and a single Fermi arc in the surface as illustrated in Fig.\ \ref{fig1}b. For simplicity and concreteness we assume that the two Weyl nodes are related by a mirror symmetry ${\cal M}$ with $y=0$ the mirror plane. It is then natural to form Cooper pairs from ${\cal M}$-conjugate partners at crystal momenta $(k_x,k_y)$ and  $(k_x,-k_y)$. For $k_y\to 0$ we are necessarily pairing electrons with the same spin and must therefore employ odd-parity pair potential $\Delta_{\bm k}\sim k_y$. Such an odd-parity pair potential can be generated by proximity to an $s$-wave SC provided  there is a significant spin-orbit coupling present in the interface \cite{suk1}.
